                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">element Link</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                        <p>An element </p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                              a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                           <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
                  <section class="xml-element">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/assessment-plan/local-definitions/objectives-and-methods/parts/links/href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                        <h6 id="/assessment-plan/local-definitions/objectives-and-methods/part/link/@href" class="toc6 head">@href</h6>
                     </div>
                     <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/local-definitions/objectives-and-methods/part/link/@href">/assessment-plan/local-definitions/objectives-and-methods/part/link/@href</a> in the element map.</p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">attribute Hypertext Reference</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                           <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a></p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                 that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                              <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                 "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                              <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                                 resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                                 containing the link.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                  </section>

                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>An element </p>

                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks in-use">
                           <p class="nb">(In use)</p>
                           <p>This can be optionally used to define the set of controls and control objectives that
                              are assessed by this step.</p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>In the context of an assessment plan, this construct is used to identify the controls
                              and control objectives that are to be assessed. In the context of an assessment result,
                              this construct is used to identify the actual controls and objectives that were assessed,
                              reflecting any changes from the plan.</p>
                           <p>When resolving the selection of controls and control objectives, the following processing
                              will occur:</p>
                           <p>1. Controls will be resolved by creating a set of controls based on the control-selections
                              by first handling the includes, and then removing any excluded controls.</p>
                           <p>2. The set of control objectives will be resolved from the set of controls that was
                              generated in the previous step. The set of control objectives is based on the control-objective-selection
                              by first handling the includes, and then removing any excluded control objectives.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>

                        <p class="description">Identifies the control objectives of the assessment. In the assessment plan, these
                           are the planned objectives. In the assessment results, these are the assessed objectives,
                           and reflects any changes from the plan.</p>
                        
                        --&gt;

                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>The <code>include-all</code> field, specifies all control objectives for any in-scope control. In-scope controls
                                 are defined in the <code>control-selection</code>.</p>
                              <p>Any control objective specified within <code>exclude-controls</code> must first be within a range of explicitly included control objectives, via <code>include-objectives</code> or <code>include-all</code>.</p>
                           </div>

                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>

               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/local-definitions/activity/related-controls">/assessment-plan/local-definitions/activity/related-controls</a> in the element map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">element Reviewed Controls and Control Objectives</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>An element </p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">Identifies the controls being assessed and their control objectives.</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks in-use">
                        <p class="nb">(In use)</p>
                        <p>This can be optionally used to define the set of controls and control objectives that
                           are assessed or remediated by this activity.</p>
                     </div>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>In the context of an assessment plan, this construct is used to identify the controls
                           and control objectives that are to be assessed. In the context of an assessment result,
                           this construct is used to identify the actual controls and objectives that were assessed,
                           reflecting any changes from the plan.</p>
                        <p>When resolving the selection of controls and control objectives, the following processing
                           will occur:</p>
                        <p>1. Controls will be resolved by creating a set of controls based on the control-selections
                           by first handling the includes, and then removing any excluded controls.</p>
                        <p>2. The set of control objectives will be resolved from the set of controls that was
                           generated in the previous step. The set of control objectives is based on the control-objective-selection
                           by first handling the includes, and then removing any excluded control objectives.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>

                     <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace

                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                              OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                              or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                              and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                              an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                              lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                              consistency.</p>
                           <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                              was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                              of the containing object.</p>

                     </details>

                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                 with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                              <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered

                              <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                              a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                           <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>

                                 that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                              <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment

                              <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced

                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The <code>include-all</code>, specifies all control identified in the <strong>baseline</strong> are included in the scope if this assessment, as specified by the <code>include-profile</code> statement within the linked SSP.</p>
                           <p>Any control specified within <code>exclude-controls</code> must first be within a range of explicitly included controls, via <code>include-controls</code> or <code>include-all</code>.</p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="remarks">

                        </div>

                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>

                        --&gt;      
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>

                        </details>

                                 <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                    names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated

                                 <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                                 <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced

                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                        <p>An element </p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">Identifies the control objectives of the assessment. In the assessment plan, these
                        are the planned objectives. In the assessment results, these are the assessed objectives,
                        and reflects any changes from the plan.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The <code>include-all</code> field, specifies all control objectives for any in-scope control. In-scope controls
                              are defined in the <code>control-selection</code>.</p>
                           <p>Any control objective specified within <code>exclude-controls</code> must first be within a range of explicitly included control objectives, via <code>include-objectives</code> or <code>include-all</code>.</p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The <code>include-all</code> field, specifies all control objectives for any in-scope control. In-scope controls
                              are defined in the <code>control-selection</code>.</p>
                           <p>Any control objective specified within <code>exclude-controls</code> must first be within a range of explicitly included control objectives, via <code>include-objectives</code> or <code>include-all</code>.</p>
                        </div>

                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>

                        </details>

                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                    names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                    with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                                 <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                    to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                                 <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                                    that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>

                              an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the

      <section class="xml-element">
         <div class="header">
            <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
            <h2 id="/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions" class="toc2 head">terms-and-conditions</h2>
         </div>
         <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions">/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions</a> in the element map.</p>
         <div class="obj-desc">
            <div class="obj-matrix">
               <p class="obj-name">element Assessment Plan Terms and Conditions</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
               <p>An element </p>
            </div>
            <p class="description">Used to define various terms and conditions under which an assessment, described by
               the plan, can be performed. Each child part defines a different type of term or condition.</p>
            
            --&gt;      </div>
         <section class="xml-element">
            <div class="header">
               <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/parts"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
               <h3 id="/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/part" class="toc3 head">part</h3>
            </div>
            <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/part">/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/part</a> in the element map.</p>
            <div class="obj-desc">
               <div class="obj-matrix">
                  <p class="obj-name">element Assessment Part</p>
                  <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                  <p>An element </p>
               </div>
               <p class="description">A partition of an assessment plan or results or a child of another part.</p>
               <div class="value" id="">
                  <p>Value: A markup-multiline </p>
               </div>
               
               --&gt;      
               
               --&gt;      
               <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                  <summary>Remarks</summary>
                  <div class="remarks">
                     <p>A <code>part</code> provides for logical partitioning of prose, and can be thought of as a grouping structure
                        (e.g., section). A <code>part</code> can have child parts allowing for arbitrary nesting of prose content (e.g., statement
                        hierarchy). A <code>part</code> can contain <code>prop</code> objects that allow for enriching prose text with structured name/value information.</p>
                     <p>A <code>part</code> can be assigned an optional <code>id</code>, which allows for internal and external references to the textual concept contained
                        within a <code>part</code>. A <code>id</code> provides a means for an OSCAL profile, or a higher layer OSCAL model to reference
                        a specific part within a <code>catalog</code>. For example, an <code>id</code> can be used to reference or to make modifications to a control statement in a profile.</p>
                     <p>Use of <code>part</code> and <code>prop</code> provides for a wide degree of extensibility within the OSCAL catalog model. The optional
                        <code>ns</code> provides a means to qualify a part's <code>name</code>, allowing for organization-specific vocabularies to be defined with clear semantics.
                        Any organization that extends OSCAL in this way should consistently assign a <code>ns</code> value that represents the organization, making a given namespace qualified <code>name</code> unique to that organization. This allows the combination of <code>ns</code> and <code>name</code> to always be unique and unambiguous, even when mixed with extensions from other organizations.
                        Each organization is responsible for governance of their own extensions, and is strongly
                        encouraged to publish their extensions as standards to their user community. If no
                        <code>ns</code> is provided, the name is expected to be in the "OSCAL" namespace.</p>
                     <p>To ensure a <code>ns</code> is unique to an organization and naming conflicts are avoided, a URI containing a
                        DNS or other globally defined organization name should be used. For example, if FedRAMP
                        and DoD both extend OSCAL, FedRAMP will use the <code>ns</code> "https://fedramp.gov", while DoD will use the <code>ns</code> "https://defense.gov" for any organization specific <code>name</code>.</p>
                     <p>Tools that process OSCAL content are not required to interpret unrecognized OSCAL
                        extensions; however, OSCAL compliant tools should not modify or remove unrecognized
                        extensions, unless there is a compelling reason to do so, such as data sensitivity.</p>
                  </div>
               </details>
            </div>
            <section class="xml-element">
               <div class="header">
                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/parts/uuid"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>

                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uuid">uuid</a></p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A unique identifier for a specific part instance. This identifier's uniqueness is
                     document scoped and is intended to be consistent for the same part across minor revisions
                     of the document.</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      </div>
            </section>

                  </div>

            </section>
            <section class="xml-element">

                  <h4 id="/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/part/@ns" class="toc4 head">@ns</h4>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/part/@ns">/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/part/@ns</a> in the element map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">attribute Part Namespace</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the part's name. This allows different organizations to associate
                     distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                           names and associated text used in a part. This allows the semantics associated with
                           a given name to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                        <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                           to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                        <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
            </section>

                  </div>
                  <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace

                     may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                  
                  --&gt;

                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                           OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                           or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                           and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                           an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                           lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                           consistency.</p>
                        <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value

                           <p>A <code>class</code> can be used in validation rules to express extra constraints over named items of

               <section class="xml-element">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/parts/props/remarks"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                     <h5 id="/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/part/prop/remarks" class="toc5 head">remarks</h5>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/part/prop/remarks">/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/part/prop/remarks</a> in the element map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">element Remarks</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>

            <section class="xml-element">
               <div class="header">
                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/parts/parts"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                  <h4 id="/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/part/part" class="toc4 head">part</h4>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/part/part">/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/part/part</a> in the element map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">element Assessment Part</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An element </p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A partition of an assessment plan or results or a child of another part.</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>A <code>part</code> provides for logical partitioning of prose, and can be thought of as a grouping structure
                           (e.g., section). A <code>part</code> can have child parts allowing for arbitrary nesting of prose content (e.g., statement
                           hierarchy). A <code>part</code> can contain <code>prop</code> objects that allow for enriching prose text with structured name/value information.</p>
                        <p>A <code>part</code> can be assigned an optional <code>id</code>, which allows for internal and external references to the textual concept contained
                           within a <code>part</code>. A <code>id</code> provides a means for an OSCAL profile, or a higher layer OSCAL model to reference
                           a specific part within a <code>catalog</code>. For example, an <code>id</code> can be used to reference or to make modifications to a control statement in a profile.</p>
                        <p>Use of <code>part</code> and <code>prop</code> provides for a wide degree of extensibility within the OSCAL catalog model. The optional
                           <code>ns</code> provides a means to qualify a part's <code>name</code>, allowing for organization-specific vocabularies to be defined with clear semantics.
                           Any organization that extends OSCAL in this way should consistently assign a <code>ns</code> value that represents the organization, making a given namespace qualified <code>name</code> unique to that organization. This allows the combination of <code>ns</code> and <code>name</code> to always be unique and unambiguous, even when mixed with extensions from other organizations.
                           Each organization is responsible for governance of their own extensions, and is strongly
                           encouraged to publish their extensions as standards to their user community. If no
                           <code>ns</code> is provided, the name is expected to be in the "OSCAL" namespace.</p>
                        <p>To ensure a <code>ns</code> is unique to an organization and naming conflicts are avoided, a URI containing a
                           DNS or other globally defined organization name should be used. For example, if FedRAMP
                           and DoD both extend OSCAL, FedRAMP will use the <code>ns</code> "https://fedramp.gov", while DoD will use the <code>ns</code> "https://defense.gov" for any organization specific <code>name</code>.</p>
                        <p>Tools that process OSCAL content are not required to interpret unrecognized OSCAL
                           extensions; however, OSCAL compliant tools should not modify or remove unrecognized
                           extensions, unless there is a compelling reason to do so, such as data sensitivity.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
            </section>
            <section class="xml-element">
               <div class="header">
                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/parts/links"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>

               </div>

               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">element Link</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An element </p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                           a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                        <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <section class="xml-element">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/parts/links/href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                     <h5 id="/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/part/link/@href" class="toc5 head">@href</h5>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/part/link/@href">/assessment-plan/terms-and-conditions/part/link/@href</a> in the element map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Hypertext Reference</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                              resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

      <section class="xml-element">
         <div class="header">
            <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
            <h2 id="/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls" class="toc2 head">reviewed-controls</h2>
         </div>
         <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls">/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls</a> in the element map.</p>
         <div class="obj-desc">
            <div class="obj-matrix">
               <p class="obj-name">element Reviewed Controls and Control Objectives</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
               <p>An element </p>
            </div>
            <p class="description">Identifies the controls being assessed and their control objectives.</p>
            <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
               <summary>Remarks</summary>
               <div class="remarks">
                  <p>In the context of an assessment plan, this construct is used to identify the controls
                     and control objectives that are to be assessed. In the context of an assessment result,
                     this construct is used to identify the actual controls and objectives that were assessed,
                     reflecting any changes from the plan.</p>
                  <p>When resolving the selection of controls and control objectives, the following processing
                     will occur:</p>
                  <p>1. Controls will be resolved by creating a set of controls based on the control-selections
                     by first handling the includes, and then removing any excluded controls.</p>
                  <p>2. The set of control objectives will be resolved from the set of controls that was
                     generated in the previous step. The set of control objectives is based on the control-objective-selection
                     by first handling the includes, and then removing any excluded control objectives.</p>
               </div>
            </details>
         </div>

            <div class="header">
               <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/description"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>

            <div class="obj-desc">
               <div class="obj-matrix">
                  <p class="obj-name">element Property</p>
                  <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                  <p>An element </p>
               </div>
               <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                  qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                  may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
               <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                  <summary>Remarks</summary>
                  <div class="remarks">
                     <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                        OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                        or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                        and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                        an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                        lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                        consistency.</p>
                     <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                        was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                        of the containing object.</p>
                  </div>
               </details>
            </div>

                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                     associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                           names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                           with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                        <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                           to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                        <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
            </section>

            </div>
            <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-selection">/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-selection</a> in the element map.</p>
            <div class="obj-desc">
               <div class="obj-matrix">
                  <p class="obj-name">element Assessed Controls</p>
                  <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                  <p>An element </p>
               </div>
               <p class="description">Identifies the controls being assessed. In the assessment plan, these are the planned
                  controls. In the assessment results, these are the actual controls, and reflects any
                  changes from the plan.</p>
               <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                  <summary>Remarks</summary>
                  <div class="remarks">
                     <p>The <code>include-all</code>, specifies all control identified in the <strong>baseline</strong> are included in the scope if this assessment, as specified by the <code>include-profile</code> statement within the linked SSP.</p>
                     <p>Any control specified within <code>exclude-controls</code> must first be within a range of explicitly included controls, via <code>include-controls</code> or <code>include-all</code>.</p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="remarks">
                     <p>The <code>include-all</code>, specifies all control identified in the <strong>baseline</strong> are included in the scope if this assessment, as specified by the <code>include-profile</code> statement within the linked SSP.</p>
                     <p>Any control specified within <code>exclude-controls</code> must first be within a range of explicitly included controls, via <code>include-controls</code> or <code>include-all</code>.</p>
                  </div>
               </details>
            </div>

                     <p>An element </p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                     qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                     may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                           OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                           or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                           and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                           an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                           lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                           consistency.</p>
                        <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                           was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                           of the containing object.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>

                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

            <div class="header">

               <h3 id="/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-objective-selection" class="toc3 head">control-objective-selection</h3>
            </div>
            <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-objective-selection">/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-objective-selection</a> in the element map.</p>
            <div class="obj-desc">
               <div class="obj-matrix">
                  <p class="obj-name">element Referenced Control Objectives</p>
                  <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                  <p>An element </p>
               </div>
               <p class="description">Identifies the control objectives of the assessment. In the assessment plan, these
                  are the planned objectives. In the assessment results, these are the assessed objectives,
                  and reflects any changes from the plan.</p>
               <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                  <summary>Remarks</summary>
                  <div class="remarks">
                     <p>The <code>include-all</code> field, specifies all control objectives for any in-scope control. In-scope controls
                        are defined in the <code>control-selection</code>.</p>
                     <p>Any control objective specified within <code>exclude-controls</code> must first be within a range of explicitly included control objectives, via <code>include-objectives</code> or <code>include-all</code>.</p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="remarks">
                     <p>The <code>include-all</code> field, specifies all control objectives for any in-scope control. In-scope controls
                        are defined in the <code>control-selection</code>.</p>
                     <p>Any control objective specified within <code>exclude-controls</code> must first be within a range of explicitly included control objectives, via <code>include-objectives</code> or <code>include-all</code>.</p>
                  </div>
               </details>
            </div>
            <section class="xml-element">
               <div class="header">

               </div>

               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">element Property</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An element </p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                     qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                     may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                           OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                           or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                           and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                           an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                           lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                           consistency.</p>
                        <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                           was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                           of the containing object.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <section class="xml-element">

                     <div class="obj-matrix">

                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-objective-selection/prop/@ns">/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-objective-selection/prop/@ns</a> in the element map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="xml-element">

               <div class="header">
                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-objective-selections/links"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>

               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-objective-selection/link">/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-objective-selection/link</a> in the element map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">

                     <p>An element </p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                           a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                        <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <section class="xml-element">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-objective-selections/links/href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>

                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-objective-selection/link/@href">/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-objective-selection/link/@href</a> in the element map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Hypertext Reference</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                              resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

         </div>
         <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject">/assessment-plan/assessment-subject</a> in the element map.</p>
         <div class="obj-desc">
            <div class="obj-matrix">
               <p class="obj-name">element Subject of Assessment</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
               <p>An element </p>
            </div>
            <p class="description">Identifies system elements being assessed, such as components, inventory items, and
               locations. In the assessment plan, this identifies a planned assessment subject. In
               the assessment results this is an actual assessment subject, and reflects any changes
               from the plan. exactly what will be the focus of this assessment. Any subjects not
               identified in this way are out-of-scope.</p>
            <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
               <summary>Remarks</summary>
               <div class="remarks">
                  <p>Processing of an include/exclude pair starts with processing the include, then removing
                     matching entries in the exclude.</p>
               </div>
            </details>
         </div>
         <section class="xml-element">

            </div>
            <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/prop">/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/prop</a> in the element map.</p>
            <div class="obj-desc">
               <div class="obj-matrix">
                  <p class="obj-name">element Property</p>
                  <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                  <p>An element </p>
               </div>
               <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                  qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                  may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
               <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                  <summary>Remarks</summary>
                  <div class="remarks">
                     <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                        OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                        or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                        and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                        an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                        lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                        consistency.</p>
                     <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                        was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                        of the containing object.</p>
                  </div>
               </details>
            </div>
            <section class="xml-element">
               <div class="header">

               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/prop/@name">/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/prop/@name</a> in the element map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">

                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>

                  --&gt;      </div>
            </section>
            <section class="xml-element">

               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/prop/@uuid">/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/prop/@uuid</a> in the element map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Universally Unique Identifier</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uuid">uuid</a></p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                     document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                     of the document.</p>
               </div>
            </section>
            <section class="xml-element">
               <div class="header">
                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/props/ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                  <h4 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/prop/@ns" class="toc4 head">@ns</h4>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/prop/@ns">/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/prop/@ns</a> in the element map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Namespace</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                     associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                           names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                           with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                        <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                           to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                        <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
            </section>
            <section class="xml-element">
               <div class="header">
                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/props/value"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>

               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/prop/@value">/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/prop/@value</a> in the element map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Value</p>

               </div>
            </section>

                  </div>

                     multiple properties of the same object with the same <code>name</code> and <code>ns</code>. </p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">

                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>

         <section class="xml-element">
            <div class="header">
               <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/links"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
               <h3 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/link" class="toc3 head">link</h3>
            </div>
            <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/link">/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/link</a> in the element map.</p>
            <div class="obj-desc">
               <div class="obj-matrix">
                  <p class="obj-name">element Link</p>
                  <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                  <p>An element </p>
               </div>
               <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
               
               --&gt;      
               <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                  <summary>Remarks</summary>
                  <div class="remarks">
                     <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                        a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                     <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                  </div>
               </details>
            </div>
            <section class="xml-element">
               <div class="header">
                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/links/href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                  <h4 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/link/@href" class="toc4 head">@href</h4>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/link/@href">/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/link/@href</a> in the element map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">attribute Hypertext Reference</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                     <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a></p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                           that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                        <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                           "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                        <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                           resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                           containing the link.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
            </section>

                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>

                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                        <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to

                        <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>

                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment

                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced

                        </div>

                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>

                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

               --&gt;      
               
               --&gt;      
               <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                  <summary>Remarks</summary>
                  <div class="remarks in-use">
                     <p class="nb">(In use)</p>
                     <p>Used to add any components for tools used during the assessment. These are represented
                        here to avoid mixing with system components.</p>
                     <p>The technology tools used by the assessor to perform the assessment, such as vulnerability
                        scanners. In the assessment plan these are the intended tools. In the assessment results,
                        these are the actual tools used, including any differences from the assessment plan.</p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="remarks">
                     <p>Components may be products, services, application programming interface (APIs), policies,
                        processes, plans, guidance, standards, or other tangible items that enable security
                        and/or privacy.</p>
                     <p>The <code>type</code> indicates which of these component types is represented.</p>
                     <p>When defining a <code>service</code> component where are relationship to other components is known, one or more <code>link</code> entries with rel values of provided-by and used-by can be used to link to the specific
                        component identifier(s) that provide and use the service respectively.</p>
                  </div>

                              <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                  </div>
                  <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                     qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                     may be expressed as a list of values.</p>

                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                           OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                           or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                           and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                           an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                           lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                           consistency.</p>
                        <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                           was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                           of the containing object.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>

                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                     </details>

                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to

                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment

                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced

                              a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                           <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>

                              <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                 "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                              <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced

                                 containing the link.</p>

                        </details>

                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
